So I sing a song of love for Julia
Even though Yoko is in a huge chunk of this song, he brings the focus back to Julia, his mom.

When I cannot sing my heart
 I can only speak my mind, Julia

Lennon was in India “opening up (to himself) regarding the feelings he had for his mother, Julia” and for Yoko Ono. John often referred to Yoko as a “mother” and so he would have also opened up about the way he felt for her as well. John was inspired by poet, artist and writer Kahlil Gibran’s quote and wrote these lyrics from it.

John wrote “When I cannot sing my heart, I can only speak my mind” [based on] Gibran’s quote “When life does not find a singer to sing her heart she produces a philosopher to speak her mind“

Her hair of floating sky is shimmering
 Glimmering in the sun

This solo by John Lennon is about his mother, Julia Lennon, who was a big influence on John’s life. This particular lyric could be describing his mother since she had long hair when he was young. In an interview with John he said the following:

“I lost her twice,” Lennon said. “Once as a five-year-old when I was moved in with my auntie. And once again when she actually physically died.”

When John was a teen he had a better relationship with his mother and spent more time with her and his step siblings such as his sister, Julia Baird. In an interview  with her, she said the following:

“As he grew older, John would stay with us more often […] John and Mummy would sit together and listen to records. […] John inherited his love of music from her […].”

Due to John only being a teen when he lost his mother, he would remember the good times and the positivity she gave him, so this lyric could be describing his mother.

Julia, sleeping sand
 Silent cloud, touch me

Ono sent cryptic postcards to Lennon when he was in India, including one that read:

Watch for me – I’m a cloud in the sky.
So I sing a song of love, Julia

There was a certain Oedipal element in Lennon’s relationship with Ono. He called her “Mother Superior”, and in this song the two women are conflated into a single object of love.

In Annie Leibovitz’s famous photograph for Rolling Stone – shot just hours before Lennon’s murder – Yoko appears as the mother, and John the helpless, naked infant. Or perhaps that’s reading too much into it…

Julia, seashell eyes
 Windy smile calls me

According to Beatles writer Ian MacDonald, Yoko helped with the writing of this song:

Her influence is detectable in the song’s haiku-like images. (She may have suggested ‘seashell eyes’, taken from the then-fashionable Lebanese mystical poet Kahlil Gibran).
So I sing a song of love, Julia

Famed singer and Beatles' close friend Donovan contributed much to the White Album, and in a 2012 interview mentions specifically this song –

Did you help John Lennon during the writing of “Julia”?
Yes, I think some lyrics and of course the finger style guitar and chords that descend.. Dear John was wanting to write of a childhood with his Mom that he didn’t have.

Half of what I say is meaningless
 But I say it just to reach you

John dismissed many of his songs as “throwaways”, and reportedly told George Martin he wanted to re-record every single Beatles song.

That didn’t stop him from continuing to write “throwaway” songs. He’d been introduced to rock and roll by his late mother, Julia, and performing had initially been, amongst other things, a way of getting his mother’s approval.

This line is a personalisation of a quote from Kahlil Gibran’s “Sand and Foam” (1926) in which the original verse reads, “Half of what I say is meaningless, but I say it so that the other half may reach you.”

Julia, Julia
 Ocean child calls me

“Ocean child” refers to his wife to be, Yoko Ono.  Her name, which literally translates from Japanese to “child of the sea,” is clearly yearned for in the lyric.





Ono writes her name as 洋子 (Yōko) in Japanese characters – 洋, “yō”, meaning “ocean” or “sea”, and 子, “ko”, meaning child and a common suffix for girls' names.
Julia
The song is written for Julia Lennon, John Lennon’s mother.  She was hit and killed by a drunk, off-duty police officer when John was just 17 years old.
